natural problem: How many functions are both even and odd?  (Assume that the domain of the function is the set of all real numbers.)
natural solution: Suppose the function $f(x)$ is both and even and odd. Then $f(-x) = f(x)$ and $f(-x) = -f(x),$ so $f(x) = 0.$
Thus, there is exactly $\boxed{1}$ function that is both even and odd, namely the function $f(x) = 0.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "even f"
and h1 : "odd f"
shows  "card {f} = 1"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many functions are both even and odd?  (Assume that the domain of the function is the set of all real numbers.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 Suppose the function $f(x)$ is both and even and odd. Then $f(-x) = f(x)$ and $f(-x) = -f(x),$ so $f(x) = 0.$
 Thus, there is exactly $\boxed{1}$ function that is both even and odd, namely the function $f(x) = 0.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "even f"
and h1 : "odd f"
shows  "card {f} = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a function $f$ that is both even and odd, show that the cardinality of the set containing $f$ is 1.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "surj f"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = f (-x)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. f x = - f (-x)"
shows  "card {f} = 1"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many functions are both even and odd?  (Assume that the domain of the function is the set of all real numbers.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 Suppose the function $f(x)$ is both and even and odd. Then $f(-x) = f(x)$ and $f(-x) = -f(x),$ so $f(x) = 0.$
 Thus, there is exactly $\boxed{1}$ function that is both even and odd, namely the function $f(x) = 0.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "surj f"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = f (-x)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. f x = - f (-x)"
shows  "card {f} = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Assume there is a function $f$ that is surjective (onto), and for all real numbers $x$, it holds that $f(x) = f(-x)$ and $f(x) = -f(-x)$. What is the cardinality of the set of such functions? The final answer is 1.

fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real ⇒ real"
assumes h0 : "∀x. f x = f (-x)"
and h1 : "∀x. f x = - f x"
shows  "∃! f. ∀x. f x = 0" (* there is exactly one such function: the zero function *)
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many functions are both even and odd?  (Assume that the domain of the function is the set of all real numbers.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 Suppose the function $f(x)$ is both and even and odd. Then $f(-x) = f(x)$ and $f(-x) = -f(x),$ so $f(x) = 0.$
 Thus, there is exactly $\boxed{1}$ function that is both even and odd, namely the function $f(x) = 0.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real ⇒ real"
assumes h0 : "∀x. f x = f (-x)"
and h1 : "∀x. f x = - f x"
shows  "∃! f. ∀x. f x = 0" (* there is exactly one such function: the zero function *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find a function $f(x)$ that is both even and odd. Prove that the only function that satisfies these conditions is the zero function, meaning $f(x) = 0$ for all $x$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "surj f"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = f (-x)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. f x = -f x"
shows  "card {f} = 1"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many functions are both even and odd?  (Assume that the domain of the function is the set of all real numbers.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 Suppose the function $f(x)$ is both and even and odd. Then $f(-x) = f(x)$ and $f(-x) = -f(x),$ so $f(x) = 0.$
 Thus, there is exactly $\boxed{1}$ function that is both even and odd, namely the function $f(x) = 0.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "surj f"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = f (-x)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. f x = -f x"
shows  "card {f} = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: If there exists a function $f$ such that $f$ is a surjective function, $f(x) = f(-x)$, and $f(x) = -f(x)$, how many distinct functions satisfy these conditions? The final answer is one.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "even f \<and> odd f"
shows  "{f. even f \<and> odd f} = {\<lambda>x. 0}"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many functions are both even and odd?  (Assume that the domain of the function is the set of all real numbers.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 Suppose the function $f(x)$ is both and even and odd. Then $f(-x) = f(x)$ and $f(-x) = -f(x),$ so $f(x) = 0.$
 Thus, there is exactly $\boxed{1}$ function that is both even and odd, namely the function $f(x) = 0.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "even f \<and> odd f"
shows  "{f. even f \<and> odd f} = {\<lambda>x. 0}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Show that the set of functions that are both even and odd is equal to the set of functions that always return 0.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = f (-x)"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. f x = -f x"
shows  "\<exists>!f. \<forall>x. f x = 0" (* unique function is f(x) = 0 *)
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many functions are both even and odd?  (Assume that the domain of the function is the set of all real numbers.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 Suppose the function $f(x)$ is both and even and odd. Then $f(-x) = f(x)$ and $f(-x) = -f(x),$ so $f(x) = 0.$
 Thus, there is exactly $\boxed{1}$ function that is both even and odd, namely the function $f(x) = 0.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = f (-x)"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. f x = -f x"
shows  "\<exists>!f. \<forall>x. f x = 0" (* unique function is f(x) = 0 *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find a unique function $f(x)$ that satisfies both the properties: $f(x) = f(-x)$ and $f(x) = -f(x)$. The final answer is $f(x) = 0$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = f (-x)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = - f x"
shows  "\<exists>! f. \<forall> x. f x = 0"    (* Only the zero function satisfies these conditions *)
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many functions are both even and odd?  (Assume that the domain of the function is the set of all real numbers.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 Suppose the function $f(x)$ is both and even and odd. Then $f(-x) = f(x)$ and $f(-x) = -f(x),$ so $f(x) = 0.$
 Thus, there is exactly $\boxed{1}$ function that is both even and odd, namely the function $f(x) = 0.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = f (-x)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = - f x"
shows  "\<exists>! f. \<forall> x. f x = 0"    (* Only the zero function satisfies these conditions *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find a unique function $f(x)$ that satisfies the following two properties: $f(x) = f(-x)$ and $f(x) = -f(x)$. The only solution to this problem is the zero function, i.e., the function $f$ for which $f(x) = 0$ for all $x$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = f (-x)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = -f (-x)"
shows  "f = (\<lambda> x. 0)" (* function is the zero function *)
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many functions are both even and odd?  (Assume that the domain of the function is the set of all real numbers.) The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 Suppose the function $f(x)$ is both and even and odd. Then $f(-x) = f(x)$ and $f(-x) = -f(x),$ so $f(x) = 0.$
 Thus, there is exactly $\boxed{1}$ function that is both even and odd, namely the function $f(x) = 0.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = f (-x)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = -f (-x)"
shows  "f = (\<lambda> x. 0)" (* function is the zero function *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: If a function $f(x)$ is such that $f(x) = f(-x)$ and $f(x) = -f(-x)$ for all real numbers $x$, then the function $f(x)$ is identically zero.
